user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_set_thread_name_:
```c
static int
MHD_set_thread_name_ (const MHD_thread_ID_native_ thread_id,
                      const char *thread_name)
{
  if (NULL == thread_name)
    return 0;

#if defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_SETNAME_NP_GNU)
  return ! pthread_setname_np (thread_id, thread_name);
#elif defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_SET_NAME_NP_FREEBSD)
  /* FreeBSD and OpenBSD use different function name and void return type */
  pthread_set_name_np (thread_id, thread_name);
  return ! 0;
#elif defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_SETNAME_NP_NETBSD)
  /* NetBSD use 3 arguments: second argument is string in printf-like format,
   *                         third argument is a single argument for printf();
   * OSF1 use 3 arguments too, but last one always must be zero (NULL).
   * MHD doesn't use '%' in thread names, so both form are used in same way.
   */
  return ! pthread_setname_np (thread_id, thread_name, 0);
#endif /* HAVE_PTHREAD_SETNAME_NP_NETBSD */
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
}
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment is just the closing brace of the function. There is no code after the conditional-return branches, so there is no unreachable statement in this fragment. (Note: if none of the HAVE_PTHREAD_* macros are defined the function would fall off the end without returning — that is undefined behavior but not an instance of unreachable code. Conversely, if additional code were placed after the #endif, that code could be unreachable in configurations where one of the branches returns.)
